text: hey guys I'm Alex thanks for clicking
and welcome to this lesson on English
phrasal verbs today we are going to look
at five different phrasal verbs now
these are very very common in everyday
English speaking the first phrasal verb
we are going to look at is look forward
to okay so if you say I am looking
forward to something it means that you
are excited about something in the
future you are anticipating something in
the future so for example if you work at
a job you get scheduled vacation and
your vacation is coming up in two weeks
your vacation is in two weeks you can
say I'm looking forward to my vacation
okay so if you are looking forward to
something you are excited about
something in the future okay in the
future now one important thing to note
here you can follow the expression look
forward to again you can use it in any
tense any English tense one important
thing to note is that you can follow it
with again an event so you can say I'm
looking forward to my mom's birthday
party I'm looking forward to my son's
graduation okay you can also follow it
with a verb now if you follow look
forward to with a verb the verb must be
the ing form so you must use a gerund
actually so you can say I'm looking
forward to seeing seeing my uncle this
weekend
if your uncle is a very cool guy and
you're excited about looking looking
this sorry guys if you're excited about
seeing him this weekend you can say I'm
looking forward to seeing my uncle this
weekend
okay the next phrasal verb next English
expression that we have is get along
with so if I say I don't get along with
my brother what do you think the meaning
is okay if I say I do get along with my
brother I get along with my brother this
means I have a good relationship with
him okay if I say I don't get along with
my brother I don't have a good
relationship with him so if you get
along with someone you have a good
relationship and again you can use this
expression in any tense so for example
you can say when I was younger I didn't
get along with my dad but now that I'm
older we understand each other more and
now we get along with each other okay so
if you get along with someone you have a
good relationship if you don't get along
with someone you don't have a good
relationship with that person okay
next phrasal verb is put up with to put
up with something so the example I gave
here she puts up with the subway every
morning now imagine you have to work or
you go to school every day okay every
day you must take the subway think of
the subway or the metro some of you
might know it how is the subway in the
morning in your city how is the metro in
your city some people say the subway is
very crowded there are too many people
sometimes the subway is very hot
sometimes the subway does not smell nice
okay but you have to take the subway
right if you don't take the subway
you don't go to work but you have to
take the subway and even though you
don't like it you have to put up with it
okay so to put up with something means
to tolerate something to put up to
tolerate now again you can put up with
situations you can put up with people in
your life so for example if you work at
a job where you don't like your boss but
he is your boss or she is your boss
you have to like them pretend to like
them and you can say I put up with my
boss I don't like him or her but I put
up with him I tolerate him or her okay
so if you tolerate someone again it's
something that you might not like but
you have to do so you put up with it
next we have to give up something now if
you give something up or give up
something this means that you stop doing
it you quit doing it so for example he
wants to give up smoking now as you
notice the verb here the gerund should I
say is an ING form so you can give up an
activity for example some people can say
I need to give up drinking so much on
the weekend or I need to give up texting
my friends every day I should give up
checking my email every single hour ok
so if you give up something you stop
doing it stop doing or quit something
now again you can give up an object to
inactivity so you can say I gave up
guitar if you started playing guitar you
realized it wasn't for you you didn't
like it
you gave up guitar
so you can also give up again something
it can be either an ing gerund or it can
be something like I gave up the guitar
if you don't think it's har anymore
finally we have the expression put off
now if you put off something this means
you postpone it you push it back in time
so here we have the example don't put
off cleaning your room one thing to note
again ing okay don't put off cleaning
your room not don't put off to clean
don't put off clean don't put off
cleaning your room so to put off means
to postpone or push back in time so
imagine you have a doctor's appointment
but something important happens there is
a family emergency so you might have to
put off your doctor's appointment push
it back into until another day so please
don't put off studying okay you should
study as often as you can if you want to
improve well your skills in anything not
just English in anything so today we
looked at five common English phrasal
verbs look forward to something you're
excited about something in the future
get along with you can get along with
someone you have a good relationship
with them you put up with something so
if you put up with something you
tolerate it you have to do it you don't
like it but you have to do it okay you
can give up something stop doing
something quit something and you can put
off something which is push something
back for another time into the future
okay so guys if you want to test your
knowledge of these English phrasal verbs
you can check out the quiz on an vidcom
good luck take care
you
